elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three novel heterobimetallic coordination polymers [Mn(Me-Im)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (1, Me-Im= N-methyl-imidazole), [Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n  (2, tp=1,2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine) and [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (3, bopy=2-benzoylpyridine) have been synthesized and characterized by spectroscopic methods, single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and magnetic measurements. X-ray analysis reveals that the compounds create three-dimensional coordination polymers. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements show very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the paramagnetic Mn(II) centers of structures 1, 2 and 3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The crystal engineering of new coordination polymers is currently one of the most active fields in coordination chemistry, supramolecular and materials chemistry. These compounds attracts significant attention not only for their intriguing architectures and topologies, but also due to the diverse practical applications in fields, ranging from molecular magnetism, adsorption science and gas storage to photoluminescence and catalysis .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The crystal engineering of new coordination polymers is currently one of the most active fields in coordination chemistry, supramolecular and materials chemistry. These compounds attracts significant attention not only for their intriguing architectures and topologies, but also due to the diverse practical applications in fields, ranging from molecular magnetism, adsorption science and gas storage to photoluminescence and catalysis .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The common strategy for synthesis of these compounds is based upon so called ‘‘brick and mortar’’ method, in which two complementary molecular precursors – building blocks, such as complex cations with vacant coordination sites (as bricks) and bridging anions (as mortar), are used to construction of multi-dimensional structures. This procedure offers prospect of rationally designing extended solids with desired properties by linking together molecular building blocks with specific functionality and geometry. Use of cyanometallates [M(CN)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>]<ce:sup loc="post">z−</ce:sup> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Cr<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>, Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>n<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 or 3; M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>n<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2; Mo<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>n<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3) in combination with various metal complex cations afforded numerous one-, two-, and three-dimensional cyano-bridged compounds showing interesting physicochemical properties and wide range of applications .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The common strategy for synthesis of these compounds is based upon so called ‘‘brick and mortar'' method, in which two complementary molecular precursors - building blocks, such as complex cations with vacant coordination sites (as bricks) and bridging anions (as mortar), are used to construction of multi-dimensional structures. This procedure offers prospect of rationally designing extended solids with desired properties by linking together molecular building blocks with specific functionality and geometry. Use of cyanometallates [M(CN) n ]z- (M=VII, CrIII, MnIII and FeIII, n =6, z =4 or 3; M=NiII, n =4, z =2; MoV, n =8, z =3) in combination with various metal complex cations afforded numerous one-, two-, and three-dimensional cyano-bridged compounds showing interesting physicochemical properties and wide range of applications .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In recent years, considerable effort has been devoted to the investigation of thiocyanatemetallates as building block for construction of multidimensional heterometallic coordination polymers. Thiocyanate is a highly versatile ambidentate ligand with a polarizable π system and two different donor atoms (a hard nitrogen and a soft sulfur donor centre), which can coordinate to metals through either the nitrogen or the sulfur atoms, or both. The various bridging modes of the thiocyanate ligand generate new types of network structures and gives the opportunity for forming heterometallic complexes involving various combinations of metal ion node points. Such combinations could lead to the formation of materials with useful properties deriving from the presence of the heterometallic arrays .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In recent years, considerable effort has been devoted to the investigation of thiocyanatemetallates as building block for construction of multidimensional heterometallic coordination polymers. Thiocyanate is a highly versatile ambidentate ligand with a polarizable π system and two different donor atoms (a hard nitrogen and a soft sulfur donor centre), which can coordinate to metals through either the nitrogen or the sulfur atoms, or both. The various bridging modes of the thiocyanate ligand generate new types of network structures and gives the opportunity for forming heterometallic complexes involving various combinations of metal ion node points. Such combinations could lead to the formation of materials with useful properties deriving from the presence of the heterometallic arrays .

elements.clean_text: In this paper, we present the results of our studies on thiocyanato-bridged manganese(II)-mercury(II) coordination polymers. The compounds [Mn(Me-Im)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (1, Me-Im= N-methyl-imidazole), [Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n  (2, tp=1,2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine) and [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (3, bopy=2-benzoylpyridine) were obtained by associating the tetrahedral anion [Hg(SCN)4]2- with non-saturated substituted complexes of manganese(II), and characterized by spectroscopic methods, single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and magnetic measurements.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and all manipulations were performed in air using materials as received.

Preparation of complexes 1-3 

NH4SCN (0.08g, 1.05mmol) and Hg(SCN)2 (0.16g; 0.51mmol) were dissolved in water (20ml) and slowly added to the methanolic solution of MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.1g; 0.51mmol) and N-donor ligands: N-methyl-imidazole (Me-Im; 0.,08g; 0.97mmol), 1,2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine (tp; 0.12g; 1.00mmol) or 2-benzoylpyridine (bopy; 0.09g; 0,51mmol), and stirred at room temperature for 12h.. White crystalline precipitates were filtered off and dried in air. The crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination were obtained by slow recrystallization from methanol.

(1) [Mn(Me-Im)2Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 85%. IR (KBr): 2122(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1642(w), 1611(w), 1580(w), 1531(m) and 1516(m) ν (CNMe-Im) and ν (CCMe-Im).

(2) Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 75%. IR Br): 3096(m) ν (OH); 2129(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1620(m), 1536w) and 1524(w) ν (CNtp) and ν (CCtp).

(3) [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 80%. IR (KBr): 2133(vs) and 2144(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1639(s) ν (CObopy) and 1593(m) and 1568(w) ν (CNbopy) and ν (CCbopy).

Crystal structures determination and refinement

The X-ray intensity data of 1-3 were collected on a Gemini A Ultra diffractometer equipped with Atlas CCD detector and graphite monochromated MoK α radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in  . Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the Patterson method and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as ‘cycling' on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (non-methyl) and 1.5 (methyl) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. shelxs97 and shelxs97  programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. The one of the phenyl rings of 3 is statically disordered over two sites with about 1:1 participation of domains.

IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 560 spectrophotometer in the spectral range 4000-400cm-1 with the samples in the form of KBr pellets.

EPR spectra were recorded at room temperature and 77K on a Brüker ESP 300 spectrometer operating at X-band equipped with an ER 035M Brüker NMR gaussmeter and HP 5350B Hewlett-Packard microwave frequency counter.

Variable-temperature magnetic measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL-5-type) at a magnetic field of 0.5Tesla over the temperature range 1.8-300K. <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Magnetization versus magnetic field measurements were carried out at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in the magnetic field range 0–5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Tesla.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Preparation and infrared data</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The compounds [Mn(Me-Im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Mn(bopy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) have been obtained in high yield in the reactions of [Mn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>(Solvent)<ce:inf loc="post">y</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> with [Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> at room temperature. The complex ion [Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> has been generated in aqueous solution by addition of ammonium thiocyanate to mercury(II) thiocyanate in the 2:1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M ratio. The complementary units have been prepared in separate containers by mixing methanolic solutions of MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and a suitable N-donor ligand. For <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-methyl-imidazole (Me-Im) and 1,2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine (tp), reactions were carried out in molar ratio of manganese(II) chloride to ligand equal 1:1 and 1:2. In the reaction with 2-benzoylpyridine (bopy) the metal-to-ligand ratio were equal 1:1.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetization versus magnetic field measurements were carried out at 2K in the magnetic field range 0-5Tesla.

Results and discussion

Preparation and infrared data

The compounds [Mn(Me-Im)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (1), [Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n  (2) and [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n  (3) have been obtained in high yield in the reactions of [Mn(L)x(Solvent)y]2+ with [Hg(SCN)4]2- at room temperature. The complex ion [Hg(SCN)4]2- has been generated in aqueous solution by addition of ammonium thiocyanate to mercury(II) thiocyanate in the 2:1M ratio. The complementary units have been prepared in separate containers by mixing methanolic solutions of MnCl2⋅4H2O and a suitable N-donor ligand. For N-methyl-imidazole (Me-Im) and 1,2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine (tp), reactions were carried out in molar ratio of manganese(II) chloride to ligand equal 1:1 and 1:2. In the reaction with 2-benzoylpyridine (bopy) the metal-to-ligand ratio were equal 1:1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> clearly show the presence of the thiocyanato groups. The maxima of ν<ce:inf loc="post">CN</ce:inf> strong absorptions occur at 2122<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1,</ce:bold> 2129<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2,</ce:bold> 2133 and 2114<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, indicating presence of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-NCS thiocyanate bridges . The characteristic bands of the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C and C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N stretching modes of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-methyl-imidazole, 2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine and bis(3,5dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)methane are observed in the range 1650–1510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The carbonyl group of 2-benzoylpyridine in structure <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is characterized by <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) absorption observed at 1639<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>

elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of 1-3 clearly show the presence of the thiocyanato groups. The maxima of νCN strong absorptions occur at 2122cm-1 for 1, 2129cm-1 for 2, 2133 and 2114cm-1 for 3, indicating presence of μ 1,3-NCS thiocyanate bridges . The characteristic bands of the CC and CN stretching modes of N-methyl-imidazole, 2,4-triazolo-[1,5-a]pyrimidine and bis(3,5dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)methane are observed in the range 1650-1510cm-1. The carbonyl group of 2-benzoylpyridine in structure 3 is characterized by ν(CO) absorption observed at 1639cm-1 .

X-ray studies

The crystallographic data of 1-3 are summarized in . The intra- and inter-molecular contacts  detected in the structures are collected in  . The classical hydrogen bonds exist only in compound 2 and they form C(6) and C(14) motifs of the lowest degree (respectively for O-H⋯N and O-H⋯S hydrogen bonds). In the compound 3 the short C-H⋯O and C-H⋯S intermolecular short contact can be found, and they can be classified as weak hydrogen bonds, forming C(24) and C(11) motifs, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Each Mn(II) atom of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> connects with four mercury ions through single thiocyanate bridges, and each Hg(II) ion is bridged with four manganese ions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> single thiocyanate bridges. All thiocyanate ions exist in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-bridging coordination mode and they bend substantially at the sulfur atom (C(98)–S(98)–Hg(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>96.35(11)° and C(99)–S(99)–Hg(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>93.88(12)°). As expected on the basis of HSAB (hard soft acid base) theory, thiocyanate groups bind to Mn(II) and Hg(II) ions through nitrogen and sulfur atoms, respectively.</ce:para>

All thiocyanate ions exist in μ 1,3-bridging coordination mode and they bend substantially at the sulfur atom (C(98)-S(98)-Hg(1)=96.35(11)° and C(99)-S(99)-Hg(1)=93.88(12)°). As expected on the basis of HSAB (hard soft acid base) theory, thiocyanate groups bind to Mn(II) and Hg(II) ions through nitrogen and sulfur atoms, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0105" view="all">The Hg atom, lying on a 2-fold rotation axis, adopts a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry through bonding to four S-donors of the thiocyanate groups.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">The Mn–N bond lengths, equal 2.200(3) for Mn–N<ce:inf loc="post">Me-Im</ce:inf> and 2.260(3), 2.236(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Mn–N<ce:inf loc="post">SCN</ce:inf>, are comparable with those reported in the literature for the octahedrally coordinated manganese(II) complexes . The Hg–S bond lengths (2.5265(10) and 2.5523(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and S–Hg–S bond angels (105.04(5)–116.99(6)°) are unexceptional, falling in the range confirmed for related species . The SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups are almost linear with values of the N–C–S of 178.1(3) and 178.8(3)°.</ce:para>

The Hg atom, lying on a 2-fold rotation axis, adopts a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry through bonding to four S-donors of the thiocyanate groups.

The Mn-N bond lengths, equal 2.200(3) for Mn-NMe-Im and 2.260(3), 2.236(3)Å for Mn-NSCN, are comparable with those reported in the literature for the octahedrally coordinated manganese(II) complexes . The Hg-S bond lengths (2.5265(10) and 2.5523(9)Å) and S-Hg-S bond angels (105.04(5)-116.99(6)°) are unexceptional, falling in the range confirmed for related species . elements.content: <ce:para id="p0115" view="all">To get better understanding of the intricate framework structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, topological analysis was carried out . Topologically, the metal centers create 4,4-c binodal net described by {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>} point symbol, what corresponds to the <ce:bold>pts</ce:bold> topological type. In this simplified net, the Mn nodes take the square planar geometry and have [4.4.8(2).8(2).8(8).8(8)] extended point symbol, while the Hg tetrahedral nodes are described by [4.4.8(7).8(7).8(7).8(7)] . Such net can be considered as combination of alternating rhombi and skew hexagons in the main transition metal atoms plane, and as composed from rhombi in the secondary planes (perpendicular to the above mentioned plane) formed by Mn and Hg atoms (b–d, respectively). Consideration of the polymer as a net, which consists point nodes located only at one type of metal atoms (Mn or Hg), leads to network 10-c, described by {3<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">20</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6} point symbol (<ce:bold>fcu</ce:bold> topological type) .</ce:para>

In this simplified net, the Mn nodes take the square planar geometry and have [4.4.8(2).8(2).8(8).8(8)] extended point symbol, while the Hg tetrahedral nodes are described by [4.4.8(7).8(7).8(7).8(7)] . Such net can be considered as combination of alternating rhombi and skew hexagons in the main transition metal atoms plane, and as composed from rhombi in the secondary planes (perpendicular to the above mentioned plane) formed by Mn and Hg atoms (b-d, respectively). Consideration of the polymer as a net, which consists point nodes located only at one type of metal atoms (Mn or Hg), leads to network 10-c, described by {312⋅420⋅512⋅6} point symbol (fcu topological type) .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0150" view="all">Similar to the structures discussed above, the compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> forms three-dimensional coordination polymer, in which four thiocyanate ligands of tetrahedral [Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion are linked to the [Mn(bopy)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> moiety, forming <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-NCS thiocyanate bridges. The Mn(II) ions are six-coordinated by four SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions and 2-benzoylpyridine molecule. The binding of <ce:italic>bopy</ce:italic> to the central ion occurs through the N–O chelating site and this coordination produces a five-membered ring containing an unsaturated α-iminoketo moiety. The Mn(II) ion is almost symmetrically situated between N and O donor atoms of bopy (the value Δ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d(M–N)–d(M–O) reflecting the symmetry of the chelate arrangement equals to 0.019<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Previous studies have shown that the bite angles O–M–N in the structures with α-iminoketo chelate ligands bounded to transition metals depend mainly on the size of the metal center. The smallest values (down to 67°) were found for Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> complexes and the largest angles (up to 85°) were observed for compounds with Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
. In structure <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the bite angle of <ce:italic>bopy</ce:italic> is equal to 70.90(13)°, and is in good agreement with values reported for [Mn(bopy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (70.79(4)°) and [Mn(bopy)(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (70.4(1)°) . The Hg–S, Mn–N and Mn–O bond lengths of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> fall within the normal range, and they are comparable with those reported for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and related compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Similar to the structures discussed above, the compound 3 forms three-dimensional coordination polymer, in which four thiocyanate ligands of tetrahedral [Hg(SCN)4]2- ion are linked to the [Mn(bopy)]2+ moiety, forming μ 1,3-NCS thiocyanate bridges. The Mn(II) ions are six-coordinated by four SCN- ions and 2-benzoylpyridine molecule. The binding of bopy to the central ion occurs through the N-O chelating site and this coordination produces a five-membered ring containing an unsaturated α-iminoketo moiety. The Mn(II) ion is almost symmetrically situated between N and O donor atoms of bopy (the value Δ=d(M-N)-d(M-O) reflecting the symmetry of the chelate arrangement equals to 0.019Å). Previous studies have shown that the bite angles O-M-N in the structures with α-iminoketo chelate ligands bounded to transition metals depend mainly on the size of the metal center. The smallest values (down to 67°) were found for AgI complexes and the largest angles (up to 85°) were observed for compounds with CuII . In structure 3 the bite angle of bopy is equal to 70.90(13)°, and is in good agreement with values reported for [Mn(bopy)2(SCN)2] (70.79(4)°) and [Mn(bopy)(N3)2] n  (70.4(1)°) . The Hg-S, Mn-N and Mn-O bond lengths of 3 fall within the normal range, and they are comparable with those reported for 1, 2 and related compounds .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0155" view="all">Topologically, the metal centers create 4,5-c binodal net described by {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>} point symbol, what corresponds to the <ce:bold>tcj</ce:bold> topological type. The simplification of the polymer net to the nodes (metal centers) linked by line segments leads to the Weaire–Phelan structure with hexadodecahedron cells fused by short Hg⋯Hg interactions (b).</ce:para>

EPR spectra and magnetic properties

The EPR parameters of powder spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 are presented in the  . These spectra indicated rhombic line for complex 1 and axial lines for 2 and 3 complexes.

The values χMT of complexes 1, 2 and 3 in the temperature range 10-300K are near constant. At 300K they are equal 4.22cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.82 B.M.) for 1, 4.30cm3 mol-1 K ( μ  eff =5.87 B.M.) for 2 and 4.18cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.79 B.M.) for 3, as expected for an uncoupled manganese d5 electron configuration center. Calculated Weiss constants indicate values Θ=-0.2K for complex 1, Θ=-0.2K for complex 2, Θ=-0.3K for complex 3.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0170" view="all">The slight decrease of the value <ce:italic>χ<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> at the lowest temperatures range (1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) is caused by occurrence of a very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) centers in the crystal lattice mediating through an NCS–Hg–SCN bridges.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The slight decrease of the value χMT at the lowest temperatures range (1.8-300K) is caused by occurrence of a very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) centers in the crystal lattice mediating through an NCS-Hg-SCN bridges.

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Value of magnetizations at 5 Tesla equals 4.74 B.M., 4.86 B.M. and 4.72 B.M. for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. All these data confirms presence of spin <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>

<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>/<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese (II) centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The variation of the magnetization M versus the magnetic field H have been measured for all complexes at 2K indicates linear relation to ~1Tesla and than continues Brillouin function ( ). Value of magnetizations at 5 Tesla equals 4.74 B.M., 4.86 B.M. and 4.72 B.M. for complexes 1, 2 and 3, respectively. All these data confirms presence of spin S = 5/2 and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese (II) centers.

(2) Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 75%. IR Br): 3096(m) ν (OH); 2129(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1620(m), 1536w) and 1524(w) ν (CNtp) and ν (CCtp).

(3) [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 80%. IR (KBr): 2133(vs) and 2144(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1639(s) ν (CObopy) and 1593(m) and 1568(w) ν (CNbopy) and ν (CCbopy).

Crystal structures determination and refinement

The X-ray intensity data of 1-3 were collected on a Gemini A Ultra diffractometer equipped with Atlas CCD detector and graphite monochromated MoK α radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in  . Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the Patterson method and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as ‘cycling' on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (non-methyl) and 1.5 (methyl) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. shelxs97 and shelxs97  programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. The one of the phenyl rings of 3 is statically disordered over two sites with about 1:1 participation of domains.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic measurement

Variable-temperature magnetic measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL-5-type) at a magnetic field of 0.5Tesla over the temperature range 1.8-300K. Correction are based on subtracting the sample-holder signal, contribution χ Dia estimated from Pascal constants  and equals -298, -269 and -312×10-6 cm3 mole-1 for 1, 2 and 3, respectively. The effective magnetic moment was calculated from the equation:     μ   eff   = 2.83 (   χ   M   T   )   1 / 2   ( B.M. )  .

EPR spectra and magnetic properties

The EPR parameters of powder spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 are presented in the  . These spectra indicated rhombic line for complex 1 and axial lines for 2 and 3 complexes.

The values χMT of complexes 1, 2 and 3 in the temperature range 10-300K are near constant. At 300K they are equal 4.22cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.82 B.M.) for 1, 4.30cm3 mol-1 K ( μ  eff =5.87 B.M.) for 2 and 4.18cm3 mol-1 K (μ eff =5.79 B.M.) for 3, as expected for an uncoupled manganese d5 electron configuration center. Calculated Weiss constants indicate values Θ=-0.2K for complex 1, Θ=-0.2K for complex 2, Θ=-0.3K for complex 3.

The variation of the magnetization M versus the magnetic field H have been measured for all complexes at 2K indicates linear relation to ~1Tesla and than continues Brillouin function ( ). Value of magnetizations at 5 Tesla equals 4.74 B.M., 4.86 B.M. and 4.72 B.M. for complexes 1, 2 and 3, respectively. All these data confirms presence of spin S = 5/2 and a small lowering values of magnetic moment of manganese (II) centers.

The least-squares fit of the experimental data using these equations were limited to the temperature range from 1.8 up to 300K and leads zJ' =-0.02cm-1and g =1.97 with the agreement factor R equal 1.74×10-4 for complex 1, zJ' =-0.03cm-1, g =1.99 and R =1.93×10-4 for complex 2, zJ' =-0.03cm-1, g =1.96 and R =1.75×10-4 for complex 3.
